instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the investigation of predicting COVID-19 positive samples?
Output: The investigation used attenuated total reflection (ATR) Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy to predict COVID-19 positive samples.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the predict COVID-19 positive samples?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used to predict COVID-19 positive samples included subtraction of the VTM spectra, smoothing with a Savitsky–Golay filter, calculation of the second derivative of the FTIR spectra, and rescaling absorbance values between -1 and +1.

instruction: What metric was chosen and how far can this metric go in predicting COVID-19 positive samples?
Output: The metric chosen in the related study was the accuracy metric. The related study reported an accuracy of 76.9% and 78.4% for samples of liquids 1 and 2, respectively. This means that the method using attenuated total reflection (ATR) Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy associated with machine learning was able to correctly predict COVID-19 positive samples with an accuracy of approximately 76.9% and 78.4% for the two different viral transport mediums.

instruction: How was the classification model built in the related study investigating the applicability of ATR FTIR spectroscopy associated with machine learning in predicting COVID-19 positive samples?
Output: The classification model in the related study was built based on partial least squares (PLS) associated with cosine k-nearest neighbours (KNN).

instruction: Can attenuated total reflection (ATR) Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy associated with machine learning be used as a superior method compared to traditional methods in predicting COVID-19 positive samples in oropharyngeal swab suspension fluid?
Output: Yes. Based on the information provided in the text, attenuated total reflection (ATR) Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy associated with machine learning can be used as a method to predict COVID-19 positive samples in oropharyngeal swab suspension fluid. The study mentioned in the text used this method and achieved sensitivity rates of 84% and 87%, specificity rates of 66% and 64%, and accuracy rates of 76.9% and 78.4% for different viral transport mediums.
